blocks.text: A Database Management System (DBMS) is software that allows users to define, create, maintain, and control access to databases. It provides a systematic and organized way to store, retrieve, and manage data efficiently.

list: Data Storage: Efficiently store data in structured formats.
Data Retrieval: Quick querying and retrieval of information.
Data Security: Ensure only authorized users can access the data.
Backup & Recovery: Protect against data loss and system failures.
Consistency: Maintain accurate and reliable data across multiple users and operations.

blocks.text: Think of DBMS as a bridge between the user and the data. Users can interact with data without worrying about how it is stored internally.

blocks.title: Key Insight
blocks.text: Almost all modern applications, from banking systems to social media, rely on DBMS to manage their data efficiently.

image.caption: High-level view of a DBMS architecture showing data flow and components.

blocks.text: DBMS comes in multiple types depending on the way data is organized. Some common types include Relational DBMS (RDBMS), NoSQL databases, Object-Oriented DBMS, and Hierarchical DBMS.

list: Relational DBMS: Data organized in tables with rows and columns (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL).
NoSQL DBMS: Non-relational, flexible schemas (e.g., MongoDB, Cassandra).
Object-Oriented DBMS: Stores data as objects (e.g., db4o).
Hierarchical DBMS: Data organized in tree-like structures (e.g., IBM IMS).

blocks.text: Overall, DBMS acts as the backbone for data-driven applications and ensures smooth, secure, and consistent data management across the system.
